figure_1:
Morphological and chemical
fingerprints of representative exogenous
fine particles observed in human intraocular fluids. HAADF-STEM image
(A) and the EDXS mapping (B, C) of a particle aggregate (#1 particle)
extracted from an intraocular fluid specimen, with pronounced signals
from the elements Fe and O. HAADF-STEM image (D) and the EDXS mapping
(E–G) of a particle aggregate (#2 particle) extracted from
an intraocular fluid specimen, with pronounced signals from the elements
Si, O, and N.
figure_2:
Structural and chemical fingerprints of representative
exogenous
fine particles observed in human intraocular fluids. (A) HAADF-STEM
image of a particle aggregate (#3 particle) extracted from an intraocular
fluid specimen. High-resolution HAADF-STEM image (B) of the yellow
square marked in panel (A) shows the crystalline facets of (220) of
Au2O3 and (001) of Ag2S, as indicated
by the parallel sets of white lines. The EDXS mapping of the particle
aggregate (C–F) further confirms the elemental composition
in Ag, Au, S, and O. (G) HAADF-STEM image of an additional particle
aggregate (#4 particle) extracted from an intraocular fluid specimen.
The atomic resolution HAADF-STEM image (H) of the yellow square marked
in panel (G) shows the crystalline facets of (200) of Ag2S, as indicated by the parallel sets of white lines. The EDXS mapping
of the particle aggregate (I–K) further confirms the elemental
composition in Ag, S, and O.
figure_3:
Structural and chemical
fingerprints of representative exogenous
fine particles observed in human serum. (A) Morphology of the particle
aggregate with the size from 20 to 100 nm extracted from a serum specimen
from the patient with #4 particle that was found in the collected
intraocular fluid. (B) High-resolution HAADF-STEM images of the yellow
square marked in panel (A) reveal the crystalline facet of (200) of
Ag2S. The fast Fourier transform (FTT) of the area (C)
also substantiates the crystalline facet of (110) of Ag2S. The EDXS mapping of the particles (D–F) shows the elemental
composition of Ag, S, and O.
figure_4:
Detection
of exogenous particles in human intraocular fluid and
serum samples. (A) Human intraocular fluid samples from patients with
3 typical eye diseases with blood–ocular barrier (BOB) breakdown
(i.e., proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), macular hole (MH),
and macular epiretinal membrane (ERM)) and patients with myopia (i.e.,
no obvious fundus pathological change in vessel structure) were collected.
The concentration of exogenous particles in human intraocular fluid
samples varied in different diseases, and the particle concentrations
in BOB breakdown categories appeared higher than that in myopia (B–E).
The particle concentrations in intraocular fluids are much higher
and smaller than that in serum specimens (F, G). (H) A schematic diagram
illustrating AFP transport into eyes from the blood through the damaged
BOB. (*) P < 0.05.
figure_5:
Translocation of inhaled particles into the eye demonstrated
in
the mouse model. In vivo eye nanoparticle detection was performed
by optical coherence tomography (OCT, A) in db/db mice and the control
mice. (B, C) Representative fluorescein angiography images of wild-type
C57 and db/db diabetic mice. White circles indicate the optic disc,
red arrows denote microangiomas, and yellow arrow points to the dialated
retinal vessels. Anterior segment OCT images (D–F) taken from
different groups at 8 h after intranasal administration. (G) Semiquantification
of particles in the anterior chamber. Posterior segment OCT images
(H–J) of different groups at 8 h after intranasal administration.
(K) Semiquantification of particles in the vitreous chamber. (L) Quantification
of Au nanoparticles concentration in different groups. (M, N) Visualization
of particles (red arrows) in retinal section by immunofluorescence
staining. No exogenous particles were found in the eyes of the untreated
control mice (M), while fluorescence-labeled particles were found
in the vitreous body of the exposed mice (N). (*) P < 0.05. Each point is an individual data point.
figure_6:
Schematic diagram illustrating
the discovery of a close link unveiled
between inner particle exposure and diabetes mellitus, and a possible
pathway for exogenous particles to intrude the eye, through which
inhaled particles circulate into the eye via damaged BOB.
